newsitem.title: CHINA: China moves to curb incidence of food poisoning.
newsitem.headline: China moves to curb incidence of food poisoning.

text.p: China, apparently alarmed by Japan's recent bout with food poisoning, has introduced hygiene rules for school lunches.
Under regulations passed last week by the Ministry of Health, suppliers of school lunches would have to apply for licences from local health authorities, the China Daily said on Friday.
Workers who handled or prepared school meals would have to undergo regular medical examinations, it said.
The rules were issued on the heels of Japanese health authorities outlining new hygiene guidelines last month after a food poisoning germ killed 11 people.
The germ, believed to have spread through school lunches, and infected nearly 10,000 people in Japan, most of them schoolchildren.
The newspaper said China's school lunches were not hygienic enough.
"Some meals are inadequate and pose a threat to the health of the students," the newspaper said.
"Some people sell unhygienic or even bad food to the students, some of which causes food poisoning," it said.
One inspection of kitchens in 43 primary and middle schools in Nanning in the southwestern Guangxi region revealed that none of them met national sanitation standards, it said.
